metadata.title: Title: 1 High-resolution influenza mapping of a city reveals socioeconomic determinants of 2 transmission within and between urban quarters 3 4

abstract.text: 162/150) 39 40 With two-thirds of the global population projected to be living in urban areas by 2050, 41 understanding the transmission patterns of viral pathogens within cities is crucial for effective 42 prevention strategies. Here, in unprecedented spatial resolution, we analysed the socioeconomic 43 determinants of influenza transmission in a European city. We combined geographical and 44 epidemiological data with whole genome sequencing of influenza viruses at the scale of urban 45 quarters and statistical blocks, the smallest geographic subdivisions within a city. We observed 46 annually re-occurring geographic clusters of influenza incidences, mainly associated with net 47 income, and independent of population density and living space. Vaccination against influenza 48 was also mainly associated with household income and was linked to the likelihood of influenza-49 like illness within an urban quarter. Transmissions patterns within and between quarters were 50 complex. High-resolution city-level epidemiological studies combined with social science surveys 51
such as this will be essential for understanding seasonal and pandemic transmission chains and 52 delivering tailored public health information and vaccination programs at the municipal level.

body_text.text: Next, we performed regression models with self-reported influenza-like illness as a binary endpoint for each individual. The factors associated with increased relative risks for self-reported 156 influenza-like illness in stepwise forward and backward selection multivariable analysis were: ≥3 8 higher the socioeconomic score, the higher the vaccine rate. Income showed the highest 189 correlation with vaccination rates, followed by living space and population density, respectively 190 (R 2 0.622, p=0.0067; R 2 0.618, p=0.007; R 2 0.532, p=0.0167). Self-reported vaccination rates 191 may serve as a surrogate marker for herd immunity 27, 28
However, in years with a low vaccine effectiveness (Table S4 ) this association may be weaker.

In order to monitor antibody titres over time in a healthy population across the city, we recruited Table S1 ). Before the 2016/2017 influenza season, we observed 211 that across all urban quarters a median of 21% (IQR 17-28.5%) had seroprotective antibody levels

(defined as hemagglutination inhibition titres equal or more than 1:40 31 ) ( Figure 3A) . Again, urban 213 quarters with lower socioeconomic scores also showed low seroprotection rates (e.g. Matthaeus,

Breite, Kleinhueningen and Klybeck) ( Figure S6A ). Urban quarters with higher socioeconomic 215 scores showed a median seroprotection rate of 26.1%, whereas those with lower socioeconomic 216 scores showed a median seroprotection rate of 14.6% (p=0.05). Blood donors with influenza 217 vaccination showed significant higher H3N2 specific HI titers in comparison to people who were 218 not vaccinated (p<0.0001; Figure S6B ). Similar to the survey, in this cohort net income was Table S5 ). This visualization can be

Next, we connected all identical influenza isolates between different urban quarters. Using 279 permutation tests, we observed a generally high exchange rate and complex transmission 280 dynamic between the different urban quarters. Some urban quarters showed significant 281 connections to other urban quarters. For example, isolates from Vorstaedte (VO) and Wettstein
(WE) were more identical in comparison to other urban quarters (p<0.005, Figure 3C ).

Transmission events within the same urban quarter were explored. Interestingly, two urban 284 quarters -Gundeldingen (GU) and Vorstaedte (VO) -showed influenza isolates that were 285 significantly more related to other isolates from within the same urban quarter than to isolates 286 from other quarters or outside of Basel (p<0.001, Figure 3C ). These two urban quarters show a 287 low socioeconomic score and lower pre-seasonal seroprotection rate. Phylogenetic cluster size 288 did not correlate with any socioeconomic factors (p=n.s.).

. CC-BY-NC 4.0 International license author/funder. It is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.03.023135 doi: bioRxiv preprint
Each year influenza infects millions of people around the globe 36,37 . Historically, human 292 pandemics have had devastating outcomes, and preventive measures should have high priority.

Our results reflect an unprecedented large and dense datasets of PCR-confirmed influenza 294 cases, the largest city-wide survey on influenza-like illness performed to date, and influenza genome sequences, all mapped to the statistical block level. We observed annually re-occurring 296 geographic clusters of influenza cases and incidences. These influenza hot spots were mainly 297 associated with net income, and independent of population density and living space. Vaccination 298 against influenza was heterogeneously distributed between urban quarters and dependent mainly 299 on household income. The rate of vaccination was linked to the likelihood of contracting an 300 influenza-like illness within a specific urban quarter. Finally, transmission events between quarters 301 were highly complex, but for two urban quarters particularly high levels of transmission events 302 within the same urban quarter could be observed.

Our study has certain limitations. First, in the survey, a more research-interested population may 305 have replied to the questionnaire. In particular, 37.9% of males replied to the survey, whereas in 306 a census 48.2% were males. However, the overall reported vaccination are in line with regular 307 interviews conducted by the Federal Office of Public Health of Switzerland, which report 308 vaccination rates of >30% in people with 64 years of age and older 24 . Also, the self-reported 309 influenza-like illness rates corresponds to estimated and published attack rates 38,39 . For influenza 310 diagnostic using PCR confirmation, we cannot exclude some recruitment bias, that particular 311 people with a specific demographic background are more likely to be included at a tertiary 312 healthcare centre. In order to compensate for such a bias, we also included data from other study 313 sites including a children's hospital and family doctors and a private diagnostic laboratory which 314 also covers family doctors and other non-University hospitals in the region ( Figure S7A) . Further, 315 ecologic fallacy may link certain socioeconomic factors, therefore we adjusted our analysis for 316 population density. However, when correcting for population densities, statistical associations 317 remained stable. Although, the influenza sampling for the sequencing part of the study was 318 reasonably thorough, certainly not all influenza cases could be captured as many patients with 319 influenza will not seek healthcare. Thus, some transmission links will always remain unknown.

For more detailed analyses, future studies would need to include hundreds of samples with high 321 resolution epidemiological data across multiple influenza seasons to study the changing patterns 322 of transmission over multiple years. In addition, the transmission events across urban quarters 323 . CC-BY-NC 4.0 International license author/funder. It is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.03.023135 doi: bioRxiv preprint are highly complex, driven by mobility of people living within a city and commuters, place of 324 working, and changing antibody titres of exposed patients in each year. Although we have asked 325 where a person works, we were not able to collect sufficient data for this question -only 24.6% 326 provided details and people working in the same statistical block were very rare (<5%).

Our findings provide important insights demonstrating influenza transmission patterns in a city 329 serving as a model for studying the dynamics of seasonal flu transmission and evolution within a 330 city. These results should be repeated in cities of different sizes and complexities around the 331 world to allow public health services to be tailored most effectively. It will be interesting to see 332 whether further factors concerning influenza transmission can be identified in other cities as well 333 as their role in public health measures. Importantly, since vaccination rates were strongly 334 dependent on income and linked to influenza incidences, providing better access to vaccination 335 for low income households would likely have a substantial impact on influenza transmission. The 336 knowledge gained with our study can help to tailor public health measures such as urban 337 vaccination programs to urban influenza hotspots and not just to selected target groups (e.g. high-338 risk populations with chronic illness). National vaccination recommendations often only include a 339 selected population, e.g. health care workers, patients with comorbidities or particular age groups.
Our results suggest that such strategies may entirely miss the populations where most
This would allow us to address more and account for a greater variety of population segments 347 and help to identify potential drivers of transmission.

The overall study design has been previously published 20 . Briefly, the study had retrospective

were returned and fulfilled the quality criteria for subsequent analysis. Returned questionnaires 389 were quality controlled and the data was entered into a database. Questionnaires were excluded 390 when no information of influenza-like illness or vaccination status was reported. Influenza-like 391 illness was defined according by the WHO as a combination of self-reported fever, coughing, and 392 illness of less than ten days 41, 42 . The questionnaires allowed the option of self-identifying one's 393 place of residence within a statistical block within the urban quarter.

Relative risks for influenza-like illness and influenza vaccination were estimated by uni-and 395 multivariable Poisson regression with robust error variance. To deal with possible confounding, 396 all variables found to differ significantly in univariable analyses between participants with and 397 without ILI and with and without influenza vaccination, respectively, were included in the 398 multivariable generalized linear models. A Bonferroni-adjusted p-value threshold was applied to 399 select variables for inclusion into the multivariable models. Poisson regression models using 400 stepwise forward and backward selection were applied to identify variables independently 401 associated with both primary outcomes.
To account for socioeconomic differences related to each urban quarter and potentially

Sample collection. At 12 study sites we recruited paediatric and adult patients fulfilling the 411 following criteria: cough, fever, and sudden disease onset -these patients with influenza-like 412 illness were further evaluated using the previously described influenza specific PCR. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.03.023135 doi: bioRxiv preprint

Details regarding the sequencing have been previously described 33 100. Sites with a coverage of less than 100 were assumed to be unknown and were denoted as 436 N, that is any possible nucleotide. Sequences that showed a read depth of 100 for at least 80% 437 of the positions in at least four segments were used for the analysis. Non double infections with 438 two strains were noted. Using these parameters, we continued our analysis using 663 samples.
body_text.section: Whole genome sequencing and data analysis.

Phylogenetic trees of initial clusters. We next estimated rates of evolution for each segment using 741 the SRD06 model 60 and a strict clock model, from 200 full genome sequences sampled in 742 California, New York and Europe between 2010 and 2015, using Beast 2.5 61 . Apart from this, 743 these sequences were not otherwise used in the analysis, and as such are an independent 744 dataset. We allowed each segment to have its own phylogeny in order to avoid the possibility of 745 a reassortment biasing the estimates of evolutionary rates. Each of the segments, as well as the 746 first two and third codon position was allowed to have its own rate scaler. We ran ten independent 747 Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) chains each for 10 8 iterations and then combined them after 748 a burn-in of 10%. These estimated evolutionary rates are long-term rates of influenza A/H3N2.

We next reconstructed the phylogenetic trees of all initial clusters by using the full genomes of all 751 samples from the initial clusters. We fixed the evolutionary rates to be equal to the mean 752 evolutionary rates as estimated using the methods above. As a population model, we used a 753 . CC-BY-NC 4.0 International license author/funder. It is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.03.023135 doi: bioRxiv preprint constant coalescent model with an estimated effective population size that was shared among all 754 initial clusters. We then estimated a distribution of phylogenies for each initial cluster, assuming 755 that all segments share the same phylogeny. As estimated in the previous analysis, reassortment 756 will not bias evolutionary rates.

Local cluster identification. To identify sets of sequences from Basel that were likely to have been 759 transmitted locally, we reconstructed the geographic origins of lineages that were introduced into 760 Basel. Therefore, we used the phylogenetic tree distributions for each initial cluster to reconstruct 761 the ancestral states using parsimony. We made some modifications to the standard algorithm for 762 parsimony ancestral state reconstruction to reflect our prior assumption, that Basel is unlikely to 763 act as a relevant source of influenza on a global scale. If any descendent was not in Basel, the 764 node was classified as "not Basel". Since the influenza season covers only a few months, we 765 additionally assumed that lineages are unlikely to persist in Basel for more than 5 weeks (0.1 766 years) without being sampled. To reflect this assumption, we classified internal nodes that are 767 more than 0.1 years from a sample from Basel to be either outside of Basel, or to be in an unknown

Using clusters obtained from a phylodynamic approach, we obtain a similar clustering pattern 780 meaning the pattern is robust towards how we define clusters. In particular, using the 781 phylodynamic method, we identified 96 clusters of at least two highly similar viral genomes, 782 representing influenza transmission, which together incorporated 534/663 influenza strains. We The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.03.023135 doi: bioRxiv preprint contained samples from different urban quarters, and only a few clusters were predominantly 788 located within a single urban quarter (see Cluster A to C, Figure S8 ). Within the city, we observed 789 323/427 (76%) of influenza strains belong to 69 of the overall 96 clusters across this single 790 influenza season. The clusters comprised a median of 3 isolates, ranging from 2 to 42 within and 791 outside of the city.

FIGREF0.text: . Similarly, at the level of an urban quarter, 192 herd immunity strongly affected the risk of acquiring influenza-like illness during the 2015/2016 193 season. Urban quarters with a high self-reported vaccination rate showed a significantly lower 194 likelihood of influenza-like illness of the surveyed population compared to urban quarters with a 195 low vaccine rate (R 2 =0.61, p=0.01; Figure 2D). However, no protective effect against common 196 cold was observed (Figure 2E, p=0.56). Therefore, unvaccinated people living in the Matthaeus 197 quarter (MA) show an 8-times higher probability of contracting an influenza-like illness than those 198 vaccinated while in the Bruderholz quarter (BR) unvaccinated people only show a 1.2-fold higher 199 risk. We again observed the association of self-reported influenza-like illness and vaccination 200 rates (in % of returned survey) at the level of individual statistical blocks (r=-0.1182, p=0.007).

Blood donors who were influenza vaccinated had a median we investigated the geographic distribution of influenza virus diversity at the levels of cities, .herokuapp.com/community/appliedmicrobiologyresearch/Influenza-2016-2017/h3n2/ha; 251 links to visualization of all viral segments are provided in

FIGREF3.text: 252interactively explored using the narrative functions of Nextstrain. The diversity of European 253 influenza isolates was fully represented by the isolates collected from patients living in Basel and observed the same high intermixture and diversity. Although the socioeconomic scores differ 256 between urban quarters and statistical blocks, we did not observe an association we further explored viral transmission clusters in more detail. Based on previously published 262 mutation rates 34,35 , we assumed that influenza viruses accumulate an average of 10 single263 nucleotide polymorphisms during a single influenza season. Viral strains with a genetic 264 relatedness within this range were assigned as being in the same transmission cluster. A 265 sequence, which is more than 10 single nucleotide polymorphisms different from any other 266 sequence was ignored, so that a transmission cluster contains at least 2 viral strains. The 54 267 transmission clusters identified (Figure 3B) incorporated 547/663 influenza strains, each 268 comprising a minimum of two isolates, a median of three isolates, ranging from 2 to 111 within 269 and outside of the city (Figure S7D). Only 116 (17.5%) cases could not be linked to another 270 individual. Most of the transmission clusters contained samples from more than one urban 271 quarter, and only a few clusters were predominantly located within a single urban quarter (.herokuapp.com/community/narratives/appliedmicrobiologyresearch/Influenza-2016-274 2017/baselFluClusters). Removing isolates from outside the city and focusing only on 275 transmission events within city, we observed that 368/427 (76%) influenza strains belong to 43 of 276 the overall 54 clusters across this single influenza season.

FIGREF4.text: 341transmission occurs such as elderly, chronically ill, and children. Finally, this large-scale 342 interdisciplinary study may serve as a blueprint for investigating seasonal and pandemic viruses 343 on the smallest scale within a given geographical context such as a city. It may form the basis to 344 develop more effective and targeted counter-measures at the most relevant public health levels 345 e.g. at the urban quarter, or even smaller urban subdivisions and social milieus reflected therein.

FIGREF5.text: 351 and prospective parts. The retrospective study part consisted of an analysis of the numbers of against influenza during the 2015/2016 season; (ii) an analysis of influenza viruses collected 355 during the 2016/2017 season using whole genome sequencing of viral genomic sequences to 356 determine genetic relatedness, clusters and putative transmission events; and (iii) measurement 357 of influenza-specific antibody titres against all vaccinated and circulated strains during the 358 2016/2017 season from healthy individuals, allowing us to monitor herd immunity across urban 359 quarters. Particular patient groups may more likely present at a hospital and receive PCR-based 360 diagnostics -to minimize this potential bias, we also integrated data from a large private 361 diagnostic laboratory, which includes mainly non-hospitalized patients. Study teams at the 362 University Hospital Basel and the University Children Hospital collected data and recruited 363 patients for this study. In addition, a network of 24 paediatricians and family doctors also helped 364 in recruiting patients (see acknowledgments). Viollier, a private laboratory, providing its services 365 to a large number of private practices within the City of Basel, also provided samples and data.366 367Ethics and dissemination. The study is registered (clinicaltrials.gov; NCT03010007 on 22 nd 368 December 2016) and approved by the regional ethics committee as an observational study(EKNZ   369   project ID 2015-363 and 2016-01735).

FIGREF6.text: confirmed cases. Influenza specific PCRs were performed on nasopharyngeal swabs as 372 part of the routine diagnostic workup. For (semiquantitative) PCR detection all laboratories used 373 either the Xpert Flu/RSV or the Xpress Flu/RSV (Axonlab, Switzerland). For each PCR-confirmed 374case the exact place of residency was transposed to statistical blocks in order to anonymize the 375 data using a geoinformation system (ArcGIS by ESRI, Switzerland) and to visualize the findings 376 on maps. A statistical block is usually bordered from all sides by roads. In individual cases, the 377 boundary is by zone plan categories (e.g. railway areas, forest, green zone, agricultural zone, etc.

FIGREF8.text: Survey on ILI and vaccination. We selected urban quarters for the survey a priori, based on 384 identified diversity in their socioeconomic structure (Figure S2A-D). We translated the 385 questionnaire into the six most common spoken languages in the selected urban quarters in order 386 to reach a maximum population. The survey was distributed within one week after the end of the 387 influenza season. Of the 30,000 questionnaires distributed in 10 urban quarters,8,149 (27.1%)

The Pearson and deviance goodness-of-fit tests were performed to 406 assess the fit of the data to a Poisson distribution in the final regression models. Analyses were 407 performed using Stata statistical software, version 15.1 (Stata Corp, College Station, Texas, 408 USA).

FIGREF11.text: 441 muscle v3.8.31 47 and used the concatenated alignment of all segments to calculated a maximum 442 likelihood tree 8,48 using RaxML ( 49 ; version 8.2.8, options: -x 1522 -f a -m GTRGAMMA -p 1522 -443 # 100) to depict the relationship between the isolates.444 445 Identification of transmission clusters. In order to trace local influenza virus lineages, we grouped 446 the different influenza sequences into clusters using a maximum distance of 10 SNPs using an 447 in-house python script (https://github.com/appliedmicrobiologyresearch/Influenza-2016-2017). In 448 a recent publication the average evolutionary rate for influenza was determined to be 2.5×10 −3 449 nucleotide substitutions per site per year 50 . With a genomes size of 13,588 bp this equates to 34

FIGREF12.text: 454 we use the same in-house python script and clustered the influenza strains that have no detected 455 variants in-between. With this we found that 139 of 663 isolates (all full genomes) are connected 456 in 52 clusters in which the isolates are identical (0 SNPs). To identify quartiers that show increase 457 transmission within or to other quartiers, we performed a permutation test (10,000 repetitions) in 458 which the connections between quarters are compared to samples to which the quartiers are https://github.com/appliedmicrobiologyresearch/Influenza-2016-2017). The distribution of 461 clusters over time and in the different quarters were visualized using ggplot2 51 . The phylogenetic 462 trees were visualized using iTOL 52 . The transmission of isolates between different quarters was .herokuapp.com/community/appliedmicrobiologyresearch/Influenza-2016-2017/h3n2/ha and 467 https://nextstrain-468 dev.herokuapp.com/community/narratives/appliedmicrobiologyresearch/Influenza-2016-469 2017/baselFlu was produced using the Nextstrain toolchain 54 . Specifically, influenza virus A/H3N2 470 sequences were downloaded from GISAID 55 , filtered down to ~1400 sequences from 2016-07-471 01 to 2017-06-30, augmented with influenza reference viruses, and combined with sequence data 472 from this study. The resulting sequences were then aligned using mafft 56 , a phylogenetic tree was 473 built using IQ-tree 57 , which was subsequently turned into a time scaled tree using treetime 58 in 474 analogy to the analysis workflow used for the weekly updated influenza phylogenies at 475 nextstrain.org/flu. The visualization is implemented through the Nextstrain community feature.476 477The analysis was repeated for each segment of the influenza genome, as well as for a 478 concatenation of all segment. While the latter is not expected to yield trees that faithfully reflect 479 the relationship of all viruses and segments to each other, such an analysis of concatenated 480 genomes are nevertheless useful to resolve the relationship of very similar genomes.

FIGREF17.text: Influenza cases in Basel 2013-2018. The graph shows the distribution of PCR 556 confirmed influenza cases in the City of Basel at the resolution of statistical enumeration blocks.557 (A) Geographical clustering of influenza infections. A kernel density estimation across all five 558 influenza seasons from 2013/2014 to 2017/2018 was used to analyse the influenza case 559 distribution across the city. The 4 th and 5 th share of the kernels were visualized. The red clouds 560 show Influenza A cases and the blue clouds Influenza B cases. (B) As A, with underlying 561 socioeconomic score for each housing block visualized, ranging from 3 to 15. The score consists 562 of three individual factors: population density per ha, living space per person in m 2 and net income 563 in CHF. The natural break of the socioeconomic scores were used and visualized with three 564 different shades of grey. Clusters of influenza correlate with lower socioeconomic scores. (C) 565 Case load across representative examples of urban quarters (Bruderholz as less densely 566 populated and Gundeldingen as more densely populated). Each red dot represents an Influenza 567 A case. In order to not show the actual address of a patient, we set the dots in the middle of the 568 statistical block. (D) We combined Google Earth satellite images with maps showing the kernel 569 density estimates of influenza cases to indicate building density. Red clouds show Influenza A 570 cases and blue Influenza B cases, correlating with building density, reflecting population density.

FIGREF21.text: Red lines connecting two quarters indicates isolates that are identical within the same 603 transmission cluster, with the line width and colour intensity indicating the number of isolates in 604 that cluster shared by the connected quarters. Therefore, they indicate the level of transmissions 605 between two quarters. When correcting for multiple comparison, only the transmission within the 606 same urban quarters remained statistically significant (p<0.05), which is indicated as a coloured 607 bar at the basis of the circle. The darker the colour the more significant the association.

(A) Percentage of seroprotected healthy blood donors (HIA titre of 659 1:40 or above), prior to the influenza season, by urban quarter. As for smaller urban quarters not enough measurements were available, these were combined based on geographical proximity 661 and socioeconomic similarity. (B) Hemagglutination inhibition antibody titres in healthy blood 662 donors before the 2016/2017 season. Influenza A H3N2 titres against the circulating virus of that 663 season is shown in vaccinated and non-vaccinated people. (C) Net income in CHF per statistical Whole genome sequencing of influenza viruses during the 2016/2017 season. 667 (A) The distribution of study recruitment sites for children (dark grey dots) and adults (white dots), 668 and the kernel density estimates of overall influenza burden in the city. (B) Hemagglutination 669 inhibition antibody titres against the circulating Influenza A H3N2 virus and all other vaccinated 670 Influenza viruses in each patient enrolled with influenza-like illness during the 2016/2017 season.671Patients with PCR-confirmed influenza are compared against patients with negative PCR testing.

FIGREF27.text: All box blots show median and interquartile ranges. Whiskers indicate 10-90% percentile with 673 outliers. (C) The percentage of cumulative H3N2 specific hemagglutination inhibition antibody 674 titres is shown, again highlighting the difference between PCR positive and negative titres. (D) 675 Number of clusters and cluster size are shown, from the whole genome sequencing data. More 676 than 50% of the clusters comprise five or fewer viruses. 677 Cluster analysis of each influenza case genome during the 2016/2017 season based 679 on the phylodynamic model. Each dot represents a sequenced influenza virus isolate. Colour 680 reflects the host address by specific urban quarter. Each horizontal line corresponds to a local 681 transmission cluster of influenza viruses. Three representative clusters A, B and C are detailed 682 on the right using maximum likelihood trees indicating the complexity of transmission clusters 683 across time and urban quarters.

FIGREF29.text: selection: stepwise, pe(0.05): glm y x1 x2 x3 x(…) ,fam (poisson) link(logmodel (mixed effects generalized linear model) 717 meglm y x1 x2 x3 x(…) , II urban quarter:, fam (poisson) link(log)nolog eform 718 Group variable : urban quarter clustering based on nucleotide differences. We combined the Basel sequences with a global 726 sample of sequences (downloaded on 17th July 2018) from https://www.gisaid.org which had 727 been sampled between 1st January 2016 and 31st December 2017 for which at least the 728 segments HA, NA and MP were available. We then calculated the average nucleotide difference 729 between any of the sequences and the sequences from Basel. To split the dataset into 730 manageable pieces, we first grouped any two sequences from Basel together if they were within 731 an average nucleotide difference of 0.0025 per position. When the full genome for two sequences 732 was available, this would correspond to about 32 different positions on the full genome. For an 733 average clock rate of 0.005 mutations per site per year, 32 differences correspond to a pairwise 734 phylogenetic distance of about 0.5 years. Sets of sequences from Basel were only split into two 735 groups if the two closest related sequences of each group exceeded this criterium. Based on this 736 initial grouping, we added global sequences to each cluster if they were at maximum 0.0025/2 737 mutations away from any of the sequences from Basel. Factor 2 was used to reduce the number 738 of global sequences in each of these initial clusters.

FIGREF30.text: 768location. We then defined sequences to be in the same local cluster if all their ancestors are 769 inferred to be in Basel. Local clusters are obtained for each iteration of the MCMC. The exact 770 workflow, including BEAST2 input files can be found at https://github.com/nicfel/Fluinternal nodes 62 , these approaches themselves make strict assumptions that are violated when 773 studying the spread of diseases on a city scale. Also, it is further unknown how well they perform 774 when migration between individual locations is very strong. From the grouping of sequences into 775 local clusters as described above, sequences were classified into different local clusters over the 776 course of the MCMC.

FIGREF31.text: 783determined local transmission clusters by identifying groups of local isolates that are 784 phylogenetically more closely related to each other than to any isolate from the global collection 785 from GISAID (www.gisaid.org). TABREF0.text: . Briefly, samples from PCRconfirmed cases had the whole genome amplified using PCR. From the resulting amplicons we created libraries using the Nextera XT protocol and sequenced them on a MiSeq platform 420 (Illumina, San Diego, California) with 300bp paired end reads at 48-plex.Quality control and genome assembly. We collected all data in the 2016/17 influenza season as previously described 20 . In total, we sequenced 857 samples. All genomes are available at NCBI with accession numbers MN299375 -MN304713.
